reviewText:
It’s been 12 hours since I’ve finished this game, and I’m still at a loss of words for exactly how deeply it has affected me.  Perhaps this review is my attempt to sort out these feelings, but I hope it also gives others an idea of just what type of hell it plays on one’s mind.  First, a warning: Masochisia is dark, bloody, brutal, unrelenting in its depravity, and unflinching in its portrayal of evil.  If you have a weak stomach or are sensitive to visceral depictions of violence, do not play this game.  Yes, I realize that I’m starting a review meant to encourage people to buy it by dissuading others, but not all stories are made for everyone.  However, if you are indeed courageous enough to drop into the pits of despair, read on.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=552724180
As I sit here thinking upon what I have just witnessed, I am simultaneously appalled and blown away. I feel sickened, dirty, disgusted, and yet somehow enlightened at having seen a glimpse of humanity (or the lack thereof) that we rarely admit exists. The story is loosely based on serial murderer Albert Fish  whom I had read about years ago, and is like nothing I've ever experienced prior.  Having researched the game a bit before playing, I had an idea of what I was getting into, but was in no way prepared for the unsettling nature of placing myself in this man’s shoes as he traverses the path towards oblivion.

Several disturbing themes are present including abuse, self-harm and severe mental illness. The story is raw and unforgiving in its depictions of these things, which makes it all the more compelling.  There is no sugar coating the nature of its violence, no apologies made for what it is.   Masochisia shows us a broken man forced into despair only to find respite in the evil he embraces.  And as a narrative adventure, I felt complicit in his demise as I made decision after decision that I knew would only lead to his ruin; and yet I was compelled to keep moving forward.  I wanted to see the depths of his depravity, and that is where I felt the most disturbed.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=552724210
I’ve watched and read about evil, ruminating on what brings a man to commit unspeakable acts of horror, but never have I found myself so close to it personally, and in some perverse way enjoying it; that is, until I’d realized how far I had fallen down the rabbit hole, well past the point of no return.  Sure, revenge is easy to rationalize, even justify, but when things took a decidedly less “altruistic” turn and I began to see what I had forced this man to become, I was not only horrified at the game but also at myself.  Masochisia does not let you escape from your decisions, and that is where the real horror lies.

And so I sit here stunned, nauseated, but also mystified.   It is an odd thing to go into a story expecting to learn something about others only to come away having learned things about myself.  Despite the revulsion I now feel, there is also a sense of peace in this new found knowledge.  Understanding just how easily one can slip beyond the grasp of redemption, there is comfort in knowing that fate can be avoided if only one realizes it before it’s too late.

Here I was only trying to convince others of like mind to embark upon a truly profound experience, and I have gone and waxed philosophical.  If I have not yet driven you away with my musings, buy Masochisia, play it, experience it, and perhaps discover things about yourself and humanity that we deny exist.  I promise you, this is an experience unlike any other, if only you have the stomach to get through it.

Bottom Line:  Highly recommended for those who are brave enough to endure extremely disturbing themes and horrific acts of violence.   All others, stay away.

reviewText:
It's a fascinating game. Something so different that it might not be everyones cup of tea.
One question ... are you a terrible person?
Developer: Oldblood
Publisher: Oldblood
Release Date: October 9th, 2015

Warning! This is not a game for everybody! In fact it’s recommended for ages 18+ because of the following: pervasive language, violence and opressive themes.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=532954699
Developers Note: Masochisia is an experimental take on psychological horror games as a narrative. Individuals struggling with depression, abuse or mental illness may be uncomfortable with some of the themes. The experience is intended for mature audiences.

If you’re still interested in this game … May God be with you and read on!

You might be wondering why. Well the developers note and the Warning was the first text that I've seen in this game and my next course of action was to click on Get Help in the menue, which I've included at the end of this review. I think that says a lot about what you should expect of this game. Let me tell you this right here … you won’t be prepared for it. Trust me on that one.

StoryTaken straight from the Steam store page:
A young man discovers through a series of hallucinations that he will grow up to become a violent psychopath. How will he respond to these revelations? Can he change his fate? Can you even... change fate…

I found the story to be incredibly fascinating and I’ve found myself literally longing for answers through out the game.
Am I a terrible person? Can I change my fate?
What will happen to me?
Will there ever be an end? Or do I have to keep going on and on and on …

Yet again I have to point out that the story and the game truly isn’t for everyone.
Its a n unique and special experience and I really recommend to give this game a try based on the story alone since it’s a game you play for the story/experience and not for the actual gameplay.

GameplayWe’ve come to the, once could say, weakest part of the game but then again it wouldn’t be fair to say that but … It fits actually.
The thing is you move around from scene to scene and interact with certain objects using your mouse and that’s nearly about it. You have to complete certain puzzles though and I have to say that the Time one was my favorite and I really liked the idea behind it.
The other thing that you can interact with are your pills and magic needles.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=532955640
I won’t get too much into it but they’ll help you and you’ll need them.
Overall Masochisia is not a game that you’ll find yourself enjoying the actual gameplay. I mean it’s not bad by any means but it’s all about the story and experience and to be honest … The gameplay fits the game just fine.

VisualDisturbing. Freaky. Weird. Wrong. But so oh, so good!
The characters, all of them seriously, are just looking so good and everyone of them is unique and full of little details and characteristics. I loved the effect once your heart started to race and to be honest I quite enjoyed the look of the game in general.
Personally I liked how the whole background work was so subtle and really highlighted the characters in Masochisia but at the same time there’s always a little detail that you’ll stop and just take a closer look. Either because you find it good or disturbing.
I’d even go as far as to say that the art style suits the game perfectly. I couldn’t imagine it in any other style to be completely honest.

AudioThe art style in combination with the incredibly dark and disturbingly soundtrack, for the most part of the game, really give this game a rather fascinating and unique, though a very dark, kind of charm. The music is subtle and you won’t even notice any sound half the time you’re playing because you’re just so immersed into the story … well at least I was. I found myself longing for an answer. Yet the sound effect were the best and worst part of the game. During specific scenes, which you gladly don’t see, all you hear is the sound of what you’re doing. And it sound so real and so spot on … Kudos on that part. I really gives you a chill down your spine.
Overall I’m really impressed with the use of the audio in this game and it’s really spot on.

Am I a terrible person?I’ve contacted the developer Jon Oldblood and asked if he’s a terrible person to which he replied:
Yes, I am a pretty terrible person. But I don't mean to be.
And personally I really liked this response because the exact same thing can be said about Hamilton.
He is, but he doesn’t mean to be … or is he?
I mean what do you think after you’ve been playing this game … Are you a terrible person?

LettersNot going to give too much away but … Keep a good eye on your desktop once you start to play this game …

What else can I say?I have been lucky enough to get a Review Key for Masochisia in order to write a blunt and honest to God Review. Just as usual.
Personally I really, really, really enjoyed Masochisia.
Not entirely sure what that says about me though …
I hope to see more games like this in the future. It’s just a game with an entirely new, different and unique idea and I really appreciate it. I even have to say that, despite the games rather short playtime, the price is justified.
So I can safely recommend this game for everyone who’s fully aware of what he’s about to dive in to.

WARNING! THIS GAME IS NOT FOR THE FAINT OF HEART! THIS IS AN 18+ GAME!This game deals with issues such as murder, domestic violence, mental illness and self-harm. These issues are very serious and I would advise that you not play this game as it may provoke a very serious reaction or terrible flashbacks.

I’ve played my share of disturbing games but I feel this one truly deserves a stern warning to anyone considering purchasing it. It’s not a bad game by any means, perhaps it is too good of a game in that its writing and execution can conjure very real and heavy emotions in a player. Masochisia is more than a game, it is an experience.  It is a trip into a very troubled mind and the equally troubled minds around it, a story of a broken family and broken dreams.  I feel it’s safe to say no one in this game is very happy and I doubt you will be very happy after playing this game.

All that being said I do recommend this game for those who can handle it. I’m usually ok with these sorts of games but this one deliberately tried to get into your head and I found hard to avoid. I think everyone who plays this will probably be affected differently, but you will be affected.  It will leave thoughts in your head to ponder long after you finished the game. I will share a personal moment I had with the game before going over specific details of Masochisia and that would be Walter. Walter is the main character’s older brother who is in a straitjacket and muzzle, he is a masochist and begs to be beaten. He tells the tale of what happened to his face, going into uncomfortable details on how he bit his lip until it bled and then chewed off as much as he could. This unsettled me greatly for personal reasons, I even had to turn my head from the screen. The well-crafted words and unsettling art truly struck me on a very deep level. I didn’t stop playing after this but it was a scene that will haunt me for a while, signs of good writing.

And the writing is one of the main aspects of the story. You play young boy named Hamilton who has a mother that is manipulative and verbally abusive who also suffers from delusions and is probably mentally ill. Your father is an alcoholic who hates his life and is both physically and verbally abusive. And lastly is your brother Walter is a masochistic self-harmer who may very well be psychotic. Of course Hamilton isn’t safe from mental issues as he hears voices and sees things and also takes pills, though compared to the rest of his family he seems the most normal at first. As the game progresses, Hamilton loses touch with reality more and more and his actions become more drastic, killing because the angel Michael told him to do so. The story is written as it’s hard to tell what part of what Hamilton sees is real or in his mind. It’s a twisted psychological romp that I wish I could tell you more about but that would spoil the game.

What I can tell you about is the artwork. Just by looking at screenshots and the game’s trailer it’s easy to see that the art style in Masochisia is very dark and twisted. The people are gangly with drawn in faces, the trees are foreboding and monochrome. Buildings are dark holes you don’t even want to enter but know that you must. While the story is very good it’s the artwork and eerie music that complete this package. It’s not pretty at all and it shouldn’t be because this is not a pretty game. The art style looks like it’s coming from the point of view of someone mentally disturbed, a twisted view of what reality really is. The music is never perky, always grim and spooky adding to gaming experience.

Yes, in the end this is a game. It plays very well, all you have to do is point and click to move about, you talk to people and make choices during conversations while also sometimes using objects. While the game gives you different choices in the end things seem to end up the same way, just with different dialogue. The game also leaves text files on your desktop that are letters from Hamilton to the player. My only gripe comes out of laziness, it would have been nice to have a map to teleport to locations by after playing the game I realized that would take a player out of the game’s atmosphere. It would also cause one to miss out on some of the jump scares. There aren’t many, don’t worry, the game relies more on narrative to freak you out.

This game is sick and disturbing but it’s good to play a game that makes you think and feel. Masochisia is a bit on the short side, you can finish it in three hours or less which isn’t a whole lot for the price tag. However, I think the game packs a lot into those few hours that do make it worth the price and most definitely something to look at during a sale. Whatever price you pay for it I highly suggest owning this game. It’s very loosely based on the life of serial killer Albert Fish and I suggest researching it a bit more once you’re done playing the game if you don’t know the story already; it will put a lot of things into perspective and up the creepy factor a lot.

reviewText: I've watched films like saw" and various other horror films that see people tortured and very gruesomely violent deaths. They have not phased me one bit. However theres something about doing the action yourself in a videogame that makes you cringe and extremely disturbed me. Masochisia does just this.\n\nMasochisia follows the life of a mentally disturbed man. Voices are speaking to him in his head telling him to carry out the most gruesome acts. This is really the kind of stories you hear about with mentally disturbed people. It was very interesting to see inside the head of these people and see what it could really be like. A horrible thought to think about and to see but i've always been intrigued by how they might think. Obviously we can never be sure but this is as close to the experience
date:
that I hope i'll ever get to.

It is definitely not for the faint of heart in the slightest. Scenes of horrifying violence are constant in this game. While most of the actual killing isn't scene due to having a black screen you can hear the scenes in gruesome detail. You also see the aftermath of the crimes and it's definitely not nice to see. If this is not your thing then don't even consider this game.

The story of masochisia is told very well. I don't want to go into the actual story or how it is told cause I feel this would really ruin the experience.

I am not really a fan of point and click games. I didn't particularly enjoy the actual gameplay because of this. I got bored and infuriated exploring about looking for what to do. The story was what made me throughly enjoy the experience though. The gameplay is standard point and click formula with not much different. But if your not a fan of them like me don't let this put you off.

The graphics style is also a thing of beauty. The colour pallette really catches the darkness of the game. Characters look amazing as well. Animations aren't incredible but since not many exist in this then it's not too big of a deal.

While masochisia is mostly based on the shock element of the scenes it does also feature some mild horror elements. There are a few jump scares that exist that definitely did catch me off guard. They got a bit of a reaction out of me but not much. If your purely looking for a horror game then you won't find that here.

The game also has a lot hidden behind it. When you've finished the game you won't have found out everything. There are hidden codes throughout the game that reveal a lot about the story. After completing the story I would definitely recommend you look these hidden codes up cause it really does reveal some fascinating details.

Overall masochisia was a truly horrifying but amazing experience. Definitely worth playing. It's a short experience at just over 2 hours but it's worth the small asking price. The only thing that stops me giving it "a must play" rating is i'm really not a fan of the tedious point and click game formula.

After completing this game I am in a state of disarray.
Being based off the life of serial killer 'Albert Fish' I expected the game to be disturbing but what I did not expect was for it to leave a stain on my conscience, something that will not be forgotten. I can whole heartedly say that Masochisia is by far, the most abominable narrative horror I have ever experienced. It doesn't sugar coat anything, it vividly portrays atrocious topics including domestic abuse and extreme masochism.

Masochisia has taken a HUGE risk in gaming, but the outcome is impeccable. I cannot explain through words on how this game manages to achieve what it does. It is a game of no voice acting, repeated sound tracks and constant narration to read. BUT I wouldn't want the developer to change a thing.

In Masochisia, you can only move to the left or right of the screen. To me, this accentuated the illusion of being 'stuck' and being forced to only left or right, never forward. The dialogue options don't give the player much opportunity to refuse the obscene acts and escape, rather, it is forced to comply and obey. Delving deeper into the sickness of Albert's mind, the inability to move forward.

I've read many warnings about this game and I completely agree. I only recommend this game to players aged 18 years or older and to be in a stable mind frame. This game would be best suited to those whom are interested in burrowing deeper into the psychology of the human mind and are intruiged in the horror genre.

First and foremost it needs to be said that this game covers a variety of sensitive topics some people may find disturbing if you’re emotionally vulnerable or have experienced domestic abuse then this is a game to avoid. If you’re sensitive to mental health issues then once again, I really would beg you to stay away from this title. The story was so well written… in fact all aspects of the game were presented brilliantly. There’s not enough freedom as originally thought in the game however after finishing it becomes all too apparent as to why that is. The developer of this game is amazing in having covered so much and thought this game through to the psychological details they have.
The added touch found at the end also added to the already mixed emotions I was experiencing and left me questioning myself.

It was very well done and added greatly to the already messed up mind the game had given me till the end.

It's based on a true story, but that story is far more disturbing than what is shown in the game.

Making people feel like that if they suffer everyone else should, justifying their actions, making them just as cruel, or worse, as the people who made them feel the way they do. There are bad people in the world, using and abusing people, but do they really deserve death? As soon as we see it in a personal level we can very easily judge, but doesn't that make us less.. human? Can we play god?

reviewText:
Masochisia is a deeply disturbing game, covering such happy topics as masochism, sadism, physical and emotional abuse, murder and madness. In it's brief runtime it managed to be more horrifying and memorable than many other games several times its length. Every piece of the game works together to create an atmosphere of growing dread and revulsion, not just at the game's dark subject matter but the warped lens it is viewed through. Hamilton, the game's viewpoint character, is a particularly warped individual. The player is encouraged not necessarily to justify his actions, but sympathize with the madness that drives them.

Here's what the game does right:
The art, soundtrack, and subject matter combine to make a unique and memorable psychological horror experience.
The game approaches madness and mental illness in a surprisingly nuanced way, neither glorifying nor entirely condemning the aberrant thought patterns and impulses of the afflicted. It's an interesting approach, given the relative rarity of horror portraying psychosis as more than people who want to stab anything within arm's reach.
The viewpoint perspective, as mentioned above, is well executed.
There are some missteps, however.
Without being told directly from another review, I would have never known the subject of the game was  the serial killer, cannibal, and child ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Albert Fish and without that knowledge context for much of what occurs in the game is lost.
Every so often the game shows coded messages that are not required to progress but reveal additional information. Someone with little patience or preference for ciphers, such as myself, is consequently left with an incomplete picture of the game's portrayal of its subject matter.
The way the game portrays the murderous nature of its protagonist as a matter of destiny" could easily be misconstrued as justifying murder in general rather than that being the self-rationalization of a deranged and murderous mind.
So do I recommend this game? If you can withstand it

reviewText:
Masochisia is an interestingly complex game, and even now, a week after completing it, I'm unsure what to think of it. I wouldn't say it's as deeply affecting and moving as other reviewers have, however.

The premise is good, and although it has been done before, the game steered clear of the risk of becoming cliched and  predictible. Instead, the story kept me engaged and pushed me to unfold more. The cast of unnerving characters stay with you, although some of them seem too exaggerated to the point of becoming a parody of what they are trying to convey.

I'm not a massive fan of the art style used, but it does seem like a good fit to the game, and whilst I may not find it nice to look at, it isn't supposed to be. It's meant to leave you feeling uneasy, and it definitely fits that purpose well. I feel the same way about the navigation in the game. It became quite tiresome dealing with the slow movement, restricted to just scrolling left and right, but it adds to the feel of the game and I think it was a great move by the developer.

I do, however, feel like the game falls off a little at the end. The suspense seems to dissipate a little, unfortunately. I really enjoyed Masochisia, especially the few chilling curveballs thrown in by the Dev, but I feel like something is missing. I'd still highly recommend it, but I do feel like it's oversold on being upsetting.""

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I was a play tester for this game.

Do you like text-heavy Point & Click Adventures with very few puzzles? A story that has you trying to piece everything together for days after you've played through the game? Psychological horror that'll most likely force you out of your comfort zone? — If yes, then this game is for you.

Masochisia is a game that plays a lot more like a Visual Novel interspersed with some walking segments rather than an old school Point & Click Adventure or a Telltale-inspired game. It's not for its gameplay that you want to buy this game; you want to buy it for its twisted story, its deranged characters, and the way it'll mess with you. While the game does use jump scares, the true horror of the game aren't the monsters that are hiding in the dark. Oh no, the horror lies somewhere else entirely.

If any of that sounds appealing to you, then I can only urge you on to immerse yourself in this dark tale.

In case this is important to you:
How long will it take you to play through this game? About 2 to 3 hours, give or take.
How many endings does this game have? 2 as far as I know.
Is the story linear? Yes, it is.

reviewText:
FULL DISCLOSURE: I was given a press copy of this game prior to release. It is your right to disregard my opinion based on this fact, but I assure you that this has never affected, and WILL never affect, the way in which I construct this or any other review I write.

If you'd prefer a video version of this review, have a look here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1lxWK773mjc

PRESENTATION

Its visuals are entirely appropriate. I really liked the style and designs of the characters, they lended to the overwhelming atmosphere of, just, pure dread. And I’m serious when I say that; you feel like you’re drowning when you play this game. But next to all that, there were a lot of moments when I noticed that the visuals and music seemed quite pleasant. And in many ways, that made the game feel even more disturbing; 95% of the game is seen through this old TV screen style filter, so even when you feel that everything you see and hear are not disturbing, there are still elements - like the TV filter - that remind you that things are not quite right. I’d say the one thing that takes away from the atmosphere, is that maybe 5 times throughout the whole hour and a half experience there are jump scares and they don’t really fit into what is going on. This game works best when it’s being psychological with you, not when a wolf-man jumps out of the trees.

MECHANICS

Mechanically there is very little to say. I already mentioned that the game plays more like a visual novel than it does a “game” so be aware of that before you purchase. There’s some puzzles, and you often have to remember details from earlier in the game but, honestly, I though pretty much all of it was very simple. I figured everything out almost immediately because the game does hold your hand. It telegraphs the answers to puzzles pretty unsubtle-ly, which wasn’t a big issue for me but it may very well be an issue for some people.

STORY

But I wasn’t in the game for the puzzles, I was in for it’s twisted look at human psychology, and it does not limit itself to behind the screen. The game is entirely dark. There is no bright light, and I mean that in the sense that there’s no hope, almost anywhere in this game, and it is specifically designed to wear you down. That in itself will be enough to make a large number of people unwilling to continue with the game, and I think understandably so. But the game is trying it’s hardest to put you inside the mind of the protagonist, and in some ways put the protagonist inside of you. This game challenges you; it challenges your morality, it challenges the decisions you want to, or do make, throughout the game. It criticizes you for trying to justify the actions you will probably take when you play, and is ultimately unfair in the way it tells its story, and I mean that as a compliment. It sets you up for failure at the very beginning of the game, and it uses some really sick tools to send you its message. It also breaks the fourth wall in a lot in ways that are really inspired and cool, and really helps to make this experience a memorable one. I did feel that sometimes the dialogue was kind of up it’s own ♥♥♥ and melodramatic; I got a little sense of that, but I do feel it fits with the tone of the game and the person you’re playing as. And that’s all i’m gonna say about the game. I think I’ve given you enough information that you know whether or not you would like it, but the question remains; is it priced reasonably?

VERDICT

The game is $8 and I think that’s pretty bang on, if not, maybe a couple dollars too expensive. You’ll really need to judge that for yourself; but I think it’s pretty obvious that if you're the right kind of person I’m definitely recommending this to you. If what I’ve said in this review seems appealing, then I have to say you won’t be disappointed spending that $8. As I said, it’s only an hour and a half long but one; I think that length fits, and two; I think there’s enough quality that the brevity doesn’t matter too much. Really if you're playing this game, it’s for the experience, it’s for the psychological ♥♥♥♥-ups that it does well, when you finish it you will feel like you’ve been THROUGH something and that it’s had a relatively profound affect on you. I can’t say that none of that is due to raw shock factor which is a little cheap, but it’s the combination of shock, atmosphere, design, music all the elements of the game that really give it this force that hits you in just the right places to make you feel worn-down, upset and disturbed. There’s no way around it, this game makes you feel like crap and it might have something to do with it being called Masochisia. The only thing that really brings it, in my opinion, away from that goal is the unnecessary jump-scares. I recommend this to anyone who feels like this is something they might enjoy, and I have to say, I’m one of those people. I guess I should put it like this: If you enjoy being compelled, feeling strong emotions or challenging yourself, then you’ll like it. I’m tempted to say it’s not even entertainment -- there is little chance this game is going to entertain you in the usual sense of the word.

reviewText: I feel ill. As someone who knows a lot about the case of  Albert Fish  , yes, it is accurate, and it does have an impressive amount of information about the man and about his life. I was impressed by this at first. However, upon meeting the characters  Grace and Billy  , I could not with play it anymore with a clear mind.The creator did a great job of creating the game and showing people a story they have not heard before, but there are some historical facts I believe one should know about the game.  Billy Gaffney and Grace Bud were real people, real children. You reenact Billy's murder, cut him up into pieces, just like Albert cut up the real child. He was whipped, his ears cut off, eyes gouged out, and cannibalized.  He was only four years old. Grace Budd was ten, and she was also eaten by Albert Fish. He sent her parents a letter, detailing how he murdered and ate their child. I imagine there is no horror, sorrow, or pain like the kind the Budds felt.  I left a more negative review earlier, but after speaking briefly to the developer, I feel I was being unfair. It was a game with a lot of work poured into it, but I personally could not stomach it. Listen VERY closely to the warnings, and please try to understand the historical even this game was based on. IF you can continue after that, by all means. It is well put together and visually appealing, but too much for me.
